label: lem-mass-conservation-transport
title: Mass Conservation of Transport
nl_statement: Under reflecting boundary conditions on position and velocity boundaries, the integral of the adjoint transport operator applied to a function over the domain Ω vanishes, conserving total mass.

hypotheses.text: Reflecting boundary conditions on position and velocity boundaries
Transport operator as defined with these boundary conditions

conclusion.text: The integral of the transport operator over the domain Ω vanishes

proof.label: proof-lem-mass-conservation-transport
proof.content_markdown:
:::{prf:proof}
:label: proof-lem-mass-conservation-transport
**Proof.**
Integrating $L^\dagger f = -\nabla \cdot J[f]$ over $\Omega$ and applying the divergence theorem yields:

$$
\int_\Omega L^\dagger f\, \mathrm{d}z = - \int_{\partial\Omega} J[f] \cdot n\, \mathrm{d}S
$$

The boundary of the phase space is $\partial\Omega = (\partial X_{\text{valid}} \times V_{\text{alg}}) \cup (X_{\text{valid}} \times \partial V_{\text{alg}})$. The reflecting boundary conditions ensure that the normal component of the flux vanishes on both boundaries:

*   On $\partial V_{\text{alg}}$: $J_v \cdot n_v = 0$ (velocity reflection)
*   On $\partial X_{\text{valid}}$: $J_x \cdot n_x = 0$ (position reflection)

proof.strategy_summary: Integrate the equation defining the adjoint operator over the phase space domain Ω and apply the divergence theorem to convert the volume integral into a boundary flux integral. Show that the reflecting boundary conditions make the boundary integral vanish, yielding zero total flux and thus conservation.

conclusion.text: The boundary integral vanishes due to reflecting conditions, so ∫_Ω L† f dz = 0.

steps.text: Integrate the equation L† f = -∇ · J[f] over the domain Ω.
Apply the divergence theorem to the right-hand side.
Under reflecting boundary conditions, the normal flux vanishes on both parts of the boundary.
